awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  User-generated real time qualitative data processing for climate impacted model validation, integration, and augmentation
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this SBIR Phase I project is the development of an integrated methodology to use resident’s experiences about flood (and other climate change) events to validate modeling in real time, inform policy, and provide design insights for infrastructure development. It provides an integrated solution for capturing the valuable information captured by people’s direct experiences (photos, stories, and data) with climate change that are otherwise underutilized.  The team will develop a community knowledge platform that can process a mix of text and photo data submitted by residents and process it into formats usable for understanding on-the-ground impacts, flood occurrence and severity, and deliver that data to planners and modelers developing ways to better manage floods.  Data processing occurs behind the scenes and allows residents to engage with the planning processes impacting their communities in new ways, increase the access of underrepresented communities, and improve equity in decision-making.  The project will stimulate research in data sciences, generate new types of jobs in civic data systems, and improve the efficiency of public infrastructure investments.  User’s cell phones will become powerful local data collection tools allowing a direct line of communications and building trust between government decision makers, scientists, and residents.  



Advances in data science allows the analysis of heterogeneous qualitative and image data to incorporate user generated posts into large scale infrastructure planning around climate resilience.  Currently, descriptive data and photos submitted by users are manually analyzed for content.  Through novel use of natural language processing (NLP), spatial data analysis, artificial intelligent (AI) and computer vision of flood event photos, and development of an application programming interface (API) to curate data for hydrological model developers, this project automates the process of extracting the full value of community generated posts of flood events.  When successful, hyperlocal user generated posts will be processed in real time to deliver detailed on-the-ground data on flood events to planners, for model validation, and community members themselves.  The product builds innovative technologies to permit processing at scale so that any community experiencing flood events can generate real time flood data and monitor the impact of infrastructure as hydrological baselines continue to shift.  The project develops new machine learning NLP to automate the analysis of qualitative text data, keyword detection for sentiment analysis and impact, AI to extract flood characteristics from photos, and API for protecting model IP while allowing integration with external data for validation purposes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
ISeeChange (ISC) is an AI-enabled data and community engagement platform to help cities adapt to climate change. By utilizing real-time resident-generated data at the hyperlocal level, ISC empowers cities, counties, and utilities to maintain, manage, and safeguard infrastructure, enabling them to respond to and prevent extreme climate change-induced damage. While ISeeChange facilitates reporting on a wide range of climate events, its core markets and competencies are in areas of persistent and compound flood risks.

The SBIR Phase I Award (#2216888) proposed the development of novel AI tools for generating hyper-local flood severity metrics, integrating across diverse data formats, and linking observational data to deliver insights needed for urban stormwater infrastructure maintenance, design, and stewardship. The Phase I SBIR focused on the following activities: 

- Development of AI algorithms for quantifying flood severity. With the support of NSF SBIR, we developed natural language processing (NLP), computer vision, and fused multimodal machine learning models that transform user-generated stories into quantitative flood severity metrics. Our AI can extract metrics crucial for flood response prioritization, such as flood height, categorical flood level, flood recurrence, and potential root causes of flooding. Our algorithms achieved performance above 90% for flood level classification and errors below those reported in the literature for flood height prediction. When combined with our AI algorithms, user posts deliver critical on-the-ground insights on flood events to flood incident managers, as well as risk awareness to community members themselves. 

- Development of storm insights dashboard. We gathered and synthesized data on flooding cofactors that contribute to and exacerbate flooding such as tidal water levels, groundwater gauge data, riverine gauge data, and precipitation data. Leveraging this data, ISC is able to quickly and effectively classify the severity of storm events to facilitate clear and informed communication between stormwater managers and constituents. By cross-comparing user posts and local data, we are able to analyze storm impacts in specific locations reported by ISeeChange users and deliver insights on likely root causes and possible solutions to stormwater managers.

- Customer discovery and design. We worked in the field with our customers responding to stormwater infrastructure incidents and narrowed our product’s focus to municipal public works departments and water utilities responsible for stormwater management and infrastructure. We refined the design and delivery of our AI to deliver efficiency to inspections, flood incident response, and public stewardship workflows via our platforms, integrations, and APIs.

- Community in the Loop. Our Phase 1 R&D uniquely positions our platform to not only deliver critical service to our customers, but also scale resident actions to aid in the monitoring, maintenance, and stewardship of public infrastructure. Our new algorithms combined with storm insights, will prompt the public to add critical missing details and even take actions that cities need to be more responsive and resilient to climate change. 

The algorithms and workflows developed during Phase I SBIR are crucial for understanding the severity and causes of flooding and will help stormwater and infrastructure managers prioritize flood incident response more quickly and efficiently, as well as provide insights for more equitable infrastructure planning.


 

 


Last Modified: 11/30/2023
Modified by: Julia K Drapkin

    ISeeChange's Community in the loop platform for extracting flooding insights
